sn55.3:4.1: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.
sn55.3:4.2: Now at that time the lay follower Dhīgāvu was sick, suffering, gravely ill.
sn55.3:4.3: Then he addressed his father, the householder Jotika:
sn55.3:4.5: and in my name bow with your head to his feet. Say to him:
sn55.3:4.6: ‘Sir, the lay follower Dhīgāvu is sick, suffering, gravely ill.
sn55.3:4.7: He bows with his head to your feet.’
sn55.3:4.9: ‘Sir, please visit him at his home out of compassion.’”
sn55.3:4.10: “Yes, dear,” replied Jotika. He did as Dīghāvu asked.
sn55.3:5.1: Then the Buddha got dressed in the morning and, taking his bowl and robes, went to the home of the lay follower Dīghāvu,
sn55.3:5.2: sat down on the indicated seat,
sn55.3:5.4: “I hope you’re coping, Dīghāvu; I hope you’re getting better. I hope that your pain is fading, not growing, that its fading, not growing, is apparent.”
sn55.3:5.7: “Sir, I’m not keeping well, I’m not alright. The pain is terrible and growing, not fading; its growing, not fading, is apparent.
sn55.3:5.10: “So, Dīghāvu, you should train like this:
sn55.3:5.11: ‘I will have experiential confidence in the Buddha …
sn55.3:5.15: And I will have the ethical conduct loved by the noble ones …
sn55.3:6.1: “Sir, these four factors of stream-entry that were taught by the Buddha are found in me, and I embody them.
sn55.3:6.2: For I have experiential confidence in the Buddha …
sn55.3:6.7: And I have the ethical conduct loved by the noble ones …
sn55.3:6.9: “In that case, Dīghāvu, grounded on these four factors of stream-entry you should further develop these six things that play a part in realization.
sn55.3:6.10: You should meditate observing the impermanence of all conditions, perceiving suffering in impermanence, perceiving not-self in suffering, perceiving giving up, perceiving fading away, and perceiving cessation.
sn55.3:7.1: “These six things that play a part in realization that were taught by the Buddha are found in me, and I embody them.
sn55.3:7.2: For I meditate observing the impermanence of all conditions, perceiving suffering in impermanence, perceiving not-self in suffering, perceiving giving up, perceiving fading away, and perceiving cessation.
sn55.3:7.4: ‘I hope Jotika doesn’t suffer grief when I’ve gone.’”
sn55.3:7.5: Jotika said: “Dear Dīghāvu, don’t focus on that.
sn55.3:7.6: Come on, dear Dīghāvu, you should closely focus on what the Buddha is saying.”
sn55.3:8.1: When the Buddha had given this advice he got up from his seat and left.
sn55.3:8.2: Not long after the Buddha left, Dīghāvu passed away.
sn55.3:8.3: Then several mendicants went up to the Buddha,
sn55.3:8.4: bowed, sat down to one side,
sn55.3:8.6: “Sir, the lay follower named Dīghāvu, who was advised in brief by the Buddha, has died.
sn55.3:8.7: Where has he been reborn in his next life?”
sn55.3:8.8: “Mendicants, the lay follower Dīghāvu was astute. He practiced in line with the teachings, and did not trouble me about the teachings.
sn55.3:8.9: With the ending of the five lower fetters, he’s reborn spontaneously. He’ll be extinguished there, and is not liable to return from that world.”
